metadata.title: Types matter: taxonomic status of Chanodichthys oxycephalus (Bleeker, 1871) (Cypriniformes, Xenocyprididae) and some relevant species of East Asia
metadata.description: Issues concerning the identification of Chanodichthys oxycephalus are addressed. This species is a senior synonym of Ch. oxycephaloides and is restricted to the Chang-Jiang basin and adjacent lakes. Specimens previously identified as Ch. oxycephalus, represent misidentifications of either Ch. abramoides or Ch. dabryi. Chanodichthys oxycephalus, Ch. abramoides, and Ch. dabryi are confirmed as three distinct species. Chanodichthys dabryi shinkainensis is treated as a junior synonym of Ch. abramoides. Additional comments are provided on some cultrin fishes from Lakes Dongting and Xingkai mentioned in earlier literature. This study clears up the taxonomic confusion surrounding associated species.

metadata.title: Predictive Analytics framework for real-time surveillance of Antimicrobial Resistance in Food systems
metadata.description: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) poses a looming threat to global health, undermining decades of progress in human and veterinary medicine. In the United States, livestock production accounts for over 70% of medically important antimicrobial use, fueling the emergence of resistant pathogens that can transfer to humans through the food chain and environment. Existing surveillance mechanisms, such as the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS), offer retrospective insights with significant delays, limiting timely intervention. We propose a Predictive Engineering Framework that integrates IoT-enabled farm sensors, veterinary prescription records, and environmental sampling into a centralized real-time surveillance platform. By applying Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for trend forecasting and Random Forest classification for hotspot detection, our system achieves a 0.7% mean absolute error in 14-day resistance forecasts and 85% classification accuracy for high-risk events. Pilot deployments on ten Midwestern hog farms demonstrated a 22% reduction in antimicrobial use and an 18% decrease in clinical resistance incidents over six months. This framework delivers actionable insights via interactive dashboards and automated alerts, enabling proactive antimicrobial stewardship and rapid outbreak response. National-scale adoption promises to save $75 million annually in livestock antimicrobial expenditures and reduce human healthcare costs by $200 million through early resistance mitigation. We recommend integrating this platform into USDA and CDC surveillance programs to safeguard U.S. food security and public health.

metadata.title: Advancing chronic disease management through personalized telemedicine interventions in urban internal medicine settings
metadata.description: Chronic diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disorders remain leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with urban populations experiencing disproportionate burdens due to lifestyle risk factors, environmental stressors, and healthcare access disparities. Traditional models of chronic disease management, characterized by episodic in-person visits and standardized treatment regimens, often fail to address individual variability in disease progression, comorbidities, and patient behavior. Telemedicine has emerged as a transformative modality in healthcare delivery, offering potential for continuous, remote, and real-time patient engagement. However, to maximize its impact in chronic care, especially within complex urban internal medicine practices, a shift toward personalization is required. This study explores the integration of personalized telemedicine interventions into chronic disease management frameworks in urban internal medicine settings. It evaluates digital tools such as wearable biosensors, AI-driven risk stratification, and individualized treatment alerts that align with patient-specific clinical profiles. Drawing on recent deployments in urban clinics, the paper analyzes improvements in medication adherence, glycemic control, blood pressure stability, and patient satisfaction. It also examines infrastructural and policy prerequisites including interoperability of electronic health records (EHRs), reimbursement structures, and digital literacy that influence implementation success. Importantly, this work highlights how data-driven personalization in telemedicine can empower patients, enable timely clinical decision-making, and reduce avoidable hospitalizations, particularly among high-risk and underserved populations. By framing chronic disease management within a personalized telehealth ecosystem, this paper contributes to the evidence base for scalable, equitable, and proactive care models that align with the growing demands of urban internal medicine.

creators.name: Olowomeye, Eunice

metadata.title: REVOLUTIONIZING LUNG DISEASE DIAGNOSIS IN X-RAY IMAGES:  MULTI-STAGE APPROACH WITH WMF, FCM, AND MCNN INTEGRATION USING YOLOV4
metadata.description:
Asst Professor, Dept of CSE, Sardar Patel Institute of Technology, Mumbai

Email Id: routray.sanju@gmail.com

This research presents a comprehensive framework for enhancing the accuracy of lung disease diagnosis through a multi-stage process applied to X-ray images. The proposed methodology begins with the application of Weighted Median Filtering (WMF) to effectively reduce noise in the input X-ray images. Subsequently, morphological operations are employed for enhancement, refining the image quality for better analysis. The segmentation process is then performed utilizing Fuzzy C-Means Clustering (FCM), effectively partitioning the images to highlight significant regions. To extract pertinent features for classification, the framework employs a Modified Convolution Neural Network (MCNN) within an Ensemble-based classification approach. The entire process is seamlessly integrated using YOLOv4, facilitating efficient end-to-end processing. Notably, the proposed methodology achieves a commendable accuracy rate of 93.78%, demonstrating its efficacy in robust lung disease diagnosis. This integrated framework offers a promising approach to enhance the accuracy and reliability of computer-aided diagnostic systems for lung diseases based on X-ray images.

journal.title: International Journal of HIT Transaction on ECCN

data.title: REVOLUTIONIZING LUNG DISEASE DIAGNOSIS IN X-RAY IMAGES:  MULTI-STAGE APPROACH WITH WMF, FCM, AND MCNN INTEGRATION USING YOLOV4

metadata.title: MOTIVATIONAL AND ADAPTIVE FACTORS OF PHYSICAL EDUCATION CLASSES IN SHAPING A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE AMONG STUDENTS
metadata.description: This article analyzes the motivational and adaptive factors of physical education classes in shaping a healthy lifestyle among students. It reveals the pedagogical and psychological mechanisms that increase students’ active participation in the physical education process, stabilize their psychophysiological state, and strengthen the need for a healthy lifestyle. In addition, the significance of physical education classes in developing students’ social adaptability and the ways of enhancing motivational factors are scientifically explained.

data.title: MOTIVATIONAL AND ADAPTIVE FACTORS OF PHYSICAL EDUCATION CLASSES IN SHAPING A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE AMONG STUDENTS

metadata.title: mehrnegara/renal_mass_classification: Version 1.0 – Code used for manuscript
metadata.description:
This release contains the codebase and configuration files used in the paper: "Machine Learning–Based Classification of Aggressive and Malignant Renal Tumors from Multimodal Data."

Contents src/ — Model training, validation, and evaluation scripts configs/ — Configuration files used for nested cross-validation and experiments README.md — Detailed usage and setup instructions embeddings/ — Self-supervised embeddings of 4-phase CECT images (SimCLR representations) (Note: Patient-level CT images are not included due to privacy restrictions.)

data.title: mehrnegara/renal_mass_classification: Version 1.0 – Code used for manuscript

metadata.title: நிலவியல் அடிப்படையில் நற்றிணை / Geographical Based Classification in Natrinai
metadata.description: Man is a symbol of the fighting spirit. There are so many living beings that have emerged in the world that have survived many millions of years and have remained unchanged. Nevertheless, man has made immense progress through his spirit. From discovering deep-sea wonders to inventing science and technology that led to flying in the sky, it is considered a victory for man's relentless struggle. It is not a matter that how much one grows in life, science supports the development of mankind. The human mind is inclined to relax and to enjoy and experience the life-oriented arts. In Tamil Literature, Sangam literature is regarded as an asset to the indigenous knowledge and experience of the Tamils. In the Sangam literature, the Agam literature has recorded the Tamil life portraying the knowledge and experience that had been in the land and has made use of it knowing its usefulness. Man has prepared and paved the land in a way that he can live and satisfy the necessities of his life according to its nature. He has called it by various names. The Tamil land has been divided into five landscapes. Hence, the article describes how the land has been identified as mountainous, forest, agricultural, coastal and arid land as evidenced in the Sangam classic Natrinai.

data.title: நிலவியல் அடிப்படையில் நற்றிணை / Geographical Based Classification in Natrinai

metadata.title: Sensitivity-Guided Heuristic Optimization for AI Fairness and Bias Detection
metadata.description:
Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly being applied across various fields in modern society. From recruitment and credit assessment to medical diagnosis and judicial adjudication, the decision-making capabilities of AI models offer unprecedented efficiency. However, as AI applications deepen, algorithmic bias and unfairness become increasingly prominent. Bias can arise from multiple factors, including historical data, label imbalance, model training mechanisms, and user interaction. If left unchecked, it can lead to social injustice and raise legal and ethical issues. Therefore, developing an algorithm that can automatically detect and optimize model fairness while maintaining predictive accuracy is of great theoretical and practical value.

 

This paper proposes a sensitivity-guided heuristic fairness optimization (SGHFO) algorithm. Building on the traditional heuristic search and swarm optimization framework, this algorithm incorporates innovative mechanisms, including a sensitivity gradient-driven mechanism, dynamic fairness weights, adaptive dual perturbations, and bias-sensitive adversarial evaluation. By quantifying the model's dependence on sensitive attributes as a sensitivity metric and combining group bias with individual similarity, it achieves multi-objective joint optimization. This paper constructs a detailed mathematical model for the algorithm, including classification loss, group fairness loss, individual fairness loss, and bias-resistance loss, and proposes a comprehensive iterative search and update strategy and optimization process. This approach not only provides a comprehensive methodology for quantifying bias and fairness, but also offers theoretical guidance and optimization strategies for the practical application of AI models.

 

This paper proposes a new algorithmic framework and mathematical model for AI fairness and bias detection, emphasizing fairness optimization through sensitivity guidance and dynamic adjustment, while balancing individual and group fairness. It demonstrates strong theoretical innovation and broad application potential.

data.title: Sensitivity-Guided Heuristic Optimization for AI Fairness and Bias Detection

files.key: Sensitivity-Guided Heuristic Optimization for AI Fairness and Bias Detection.pdf

metadata.title: isofit
metadata.description:
Major New Feature

ISOFIT v3.6.0 introduces a multisurface classification that allows the application of different surface models within the same image (e.g., glint model for water surfaces, multicomponent model for land surfaces). Important note: This feature is still in a beta version and testing is ongoing. However, full backward compatibility is ensured.

What's Changed

  • Fixed Docker Syntax Error by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/754
  • option for faster slope based method in skyview by @brentwilder in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/748
  • Extending Isofit to handle multisurface classifications by @evan-greenbrg in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/617
  • Fixed config checks to support 6c emulator by @evan-greenbrg in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/758
  • Unclog Workflows by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/755
  • Wavelength multisurface fix by @pgbrodrick in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/762
  • Resources Flag by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/767
  • Bugfix isoplots version checking by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/766
  • Adding fwhm to analytical line outputs by @evan-greenbrg in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/764
  • Prebuilt LUT bypass config checks by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/769
  • FileResources Exception Handling by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/777
  • removing pandas from isofit by @brentwilder in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/759
  • Adapt docs.yml to isofit.yml. by @unbohn in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/786
  • h5py pinning by @unbohn in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/785
  • CLI Debugging by @jammont in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/792
  • Replace hardcoded AOE hash table size by default value from implementation config by @unbohn in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/793
  • skyview logging and error handling by @brentwilder in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/756
  • More descriptions on ISOFIT run to envi file by @brentwilder in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/776
  • 3.6.0 release by @unbohn in https://github.com/isofit/isofit/pull/795

Full Changelog: https://github.com/isofit/isofit/compare/v3.5.1...v3.6.0

(2018).  Optimal estimation for imaging spectrometer atmospheric correction.  Remote Sensing of Environment 216, 355-373.

metadata.title: Appraising cognitive status in dementia via touch-based reaction time: a preliminary machine learning study
metadata.description: People with dementia (PwD) perform cognitive-based therapeutic activities. Literature reports a variety of studies exploring relationships between the cognitive status of PwD as determined by the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) and their reaction times from a myriad of stimuli incorporated into cognitive activities. Nevertheless, these technology-supported activities usually include distracting elements, complex instructions, and unfamiliar devices for older adults, introducing bias into reaction times. The objective of this work is to appraise the cognitive status of people with dementia using reaction times from touch interaction tasks. For this purpose, a relatively simple cognitive activity (involving the intuitive tap gesture) and a 32-inch wide touchscreen were designed and implemented. Afterward, 21 PwD from a day center located in Sonora, Mexico were recruited. The participants were instructed to carry out a cognitive activity consisting of five consecutive taps and their reaction times were recorded. The collected data was analyzed using (i) a correlation analysis, (ii) a bootstrap evaluation of machine learning classification models, and (iii) a logistic regression analysis. From the empirical results, it can be concluded that there is a negative relationship between the MMSE score of PwD and the reaction times from taps. In addition, the bootstrapped mean accuracy results of the classifiers suggest that it may be feasible to automatically classify PwD.
